article.title: Freeze Casting: A Review of Processing, Microstructure and Properties via the Open Data Repository, FreezeCasting.net

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend does Figure 1 illustrate about freeze-casting research?
choices: The number of publications on freeze-casting has declined steadily since 2006.
There was a surge in freeze-casting research after 2006 with an increasing number of papers published each year.
The number of freeze-casting publications has remained relatively constant over the years.
Freeze-casting research peaked in 2010 and has declined since then.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which step in the unidirectional freeze-casting process shown in Figure 2 involves the formation of a particle accumulation region ahead of the solidification front?
choices: Suspension
Propagation
Accumulation
Incorporation

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary difference between the isotropic freeze-casting process shown in Figure 3 and the anisotropic freeze-casting process shown in Figure 2?
choices: Isotropic freezing involves a thermally conductive mold, while anisotropic freezing uses a thermally insulating mold.
Isotropic freezing results in aligned pore structures, while anisotropic freezing results in randomly oriented pores.
Isotropic freezing does not involve a sublimation step, while anisotropic freezing does.
Isotropic freezing involves random nucleation and growth of solid crystals, while anisotropic freezing promotes directional propagation of a solidification front.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the anisotropic pore structures illustrated in Figure 4 is characterized by plate-like walls aligning perpendicular to the freezing direction?
choices: Lamellar
Dendritic
Honeycomb
Equiaxed

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of information is primarily stored in the secondary tables of the FreezeCasting.net database as depicted in Figure 5?
choices: Citation data for each freeze-casting paper
Experimental data related to various freeze-casting processing steps
Property data for particles, fluids, molds, and bulk materials
Suspension stabilization data

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Figure 6, what happens to the diameter of the primary branch in a dendritic ice structure as side branching increases?
choices: It increases.
It decreases.
It remains constant.
It fluctuates randomly.

multiple_choice_question.text: What relationship does Equation 1 (ϕp =      ∙ ϕs +     ) describe?
choices: The relationship between pore size and structure wavelength
The dependence of structure wavelength on solidification velocity
The effect of binder concentration on pore morphology
The linear relationship between porosity (ϕp) and initial suspension solid fraction (ϕs)

multiple_choice_question.text: In Equation 2 (λ =     1 ∙          ), what does the exponent k represent?
choices: The average width of one pore plus the width of its adjacent wall
The solidification velocity
The dependency of structure wavelength (λ) on solidification velocity (v)
A constant
